questions.title: Passage Ⅰ
questions.article:
Scientists have observed that if mature cocklebur plants (Xanthium strumarium) are maintained on a 16L, 8D light-dark cycle (a light-dark cycle with 16 hr of light, L, then 8 hr of darkness, D), they do not flower. However, if the plants are maintained on a 14L, 10D light-dark cycle, they do flower. Three hypotheses were proposed to explain these observations.

Hypothesis 1
Mature cocklebur plants flower if, and only if, their leaves are exposed to a total of 10 or more hours of darkness each day.

Hypothesis 2
Mature cocklebur plants flower if, and only if, their leaves are exposed to a block of 10 or more continuous hours of darkness each day. If daily exposure to darkness exceeds a total of 10 hr, but is not continuous for 10 or more hours, the plants do not flower.

Hypothesis 3
Mature cocklebur plants flower if, and only if, their stems are exposed to a total of 9 or more hours of darkness each day. Leaves are not necessary for flowering. A mature cocklebur plant without leaves will flower if its stems are exposed to a total of 9 or more hours of darkness each day.

Experiments
Figure 1 shows the results of flowering experiments performed with mature cocklebur plants maintained on various 24 hr light-dark cycles. Figure 2 shows the results of similar experiments with mature cocklebur plants having various levels of defoliation (leaf removal). In each experiment involving plants with no defoliation or with partial defoliation, during each light-dark cycle, the amount of light received by the stems was equal to the amount of light received by the leaves. (Note: In the figures, a white box indicates hours of exposure to light and a black box indicates hours of exposure to darkness.)
questions.question: 1.  Based on Hypothesis 2, which of the following light-dark cycles results in flowering?

questions.question: 2.  The results of which of the following experiments support Hypothesis 1 ?

choices.B: Yes, because the plants did not flower.
choices.D: No, because the plants did not flower.

questions.title: Passsage Ⅱ
questions.article:
In mountainous regions, a terrace is made by first building a low rock wall, then creating an area of level soil behind the wall (see Figure 1). Rainfall erodes the soil from terraces at different rates depending on whether a terrace is being farmed or is being used for animal grazing.


A study done in June of one year considered 86 terraces in the same 100 km² mountainous region, all at approximately the same altitude. Each terrace was assigned to 1 of 3 categories: farmed, lightly grazed, or heavily grazed. Also studied were talus slopes, which are inclined areas composed of rock fragments and small amounts of soil.

For each terrace or talus slope, erosion was measured in 5 different locations. At each location, a 1,385 cm² area was isolated, and simulated rainfall was applied evenly to the area at a rate of 75 mm/hr for 45 min. The time to runoff (time elapsed between the beginning of rainfall and the beginning of runoff) was recorded (in sec).

All runoff from each isolated area was collected over the 45 min to determine the runoff rate (in mm/hr), the soil concentration in the runoff (in g/L); and the soil erosion rate (in g/m²/hr). The wetting front was also determined at the end of 45 min. The wetting front was the depth (in cm) to which rainwater had infiltrated the soil. The results, averaged for each of the 4 types of surfaces, are shown in Table 1.


Figure and table adapted from Teodoro Lasanta et al., “Marginal lands and Erosion in Terraced Fields in the Mediterranean Mountains.” ©2001 by the International Mountain Society and the United Nations University.
questions.question: 8.  Which of the following graphs best represents the wetting front results in Table 1?

questions.question: 9.  Is the statement "The average soil erosion rate was greatest for the talus slopes" supported by the results of the study?

choices.A: Yes; the average soil erosion rate for the talus slopes was greater than that for any of the 3 categories of terraces.
choices.B: Yes; the average soil erosion rate for the talus slopes was less than that for any of the 3 categories of terraces.
choices.C: No; the average soil erosion rate for the talus slopes was greater than that for the farmed terracesand that for the lightly grazed terraces, but less than that for the heavily grazed terraces.
choices.D: No; the average soil erosion rate for the talus slopes was greater than that for the farmed terraces, but less than that for the lightly grazed terraces and that for the heavily grazed terraces.

questions.question: 10.  The most likely reason that terraces located in the same mountainous region were selected for study was to ensure that the terraces would be as similar as possible with respect to which of the following variables?

questions.question: 12.  Do the results of the study support the statement "On average, for all 4 types of surfaces, all of the simulated rainfall that was applied ran off" ?

choices.A: Yes, because for all 4 types of surfaces the runoff rate was greater than 75 mm/hr and the wetting front was zero.
choices.B: Yes, because for all 4 types of surfaces the runoff rate was less than 75 mm/hr and the wetting front was greater than zero.
choices.C: No, because for all 4 types of surfaces the runoff rate was greater than 75 mm/hr and the wetting front was zero.
choices.D: No, because for all 4 types of surfaces the runoff rate was less than 75 mm/hr and the wetting front was greater than zero.

questions.title: Passsage Ⅱ
questions.article:

questions.question: 13.  Which of the following statements best explains why the soil erosion rate for heavily grazed terraces differed from the soil erosion rate for lightly grazed terraces? Heavily grazed terraces had:

choices.A: more vegetation cover than did lightly grazed terraces, and therefore were more resistant to erosion.
choices.B: more vegetation cover than did lightly grazed terraces, and therefore were less resistant to erosion.
choices.C: less vegetation cover than did lightly grazed terraces, and therefore were less resistant to erosion.
choices.D: less vegetation cover than did lightly grazed terraces, and therefore were more resistant to erosion.

questions.title: Passage Ⅲ
questions.article:
A capacitor is a device for storing electrical charge. Students in a science class determined the charge on a parallel-plate capacitor having a fixed capacitance (the ratio of the amount of charge on each plate to the voltage between the plates). Measurements were taken while the capacitor was being charged and while it was being discharged.


Study 1

The students constructed an electrical circuit consisting of the capacitor, which was initially uncharged, a 4-volt (4V) battery, a 1011-ohm resistor, and a switch (see Figure 1).

They closed the switch and charged the capacitor. During charging, the voltage across the capacitor, ε, in V, was monitored with a voltmeter. A computer that was connected to the voltmeter plotted ε versus time, t, in seconds (sec). The results are shown in Figure 2.


Once the capacitor was fully charged, ε equaled the voltage supplied by the battery. Using the data in Figure 2, the computer calculated the charge, Q, on the capacitor at various t, in picocoulombs (pC; 1 pC = 10-12 coulomb). The results are shown in Table 1.


Study 2

With the capacitor fully charged, the students opened the switch, removed the battery from the circuit, and substituted a picoammeter (see Figure 3) capable of measuring currents as small as 1 × 10-12 amp= 1 picoamp (pA). Then they closed the switch, allowing the capacitor to discharge through the resistor.


While the capacitor discharged, the students measured the electrical current, I, flowing through the resistor. The computer plotted I versus t (see Figure 4) and then, using the plotted values, calculated Q for various t (see Table 2).
questions.question: 14.  Between t = 0 sec and t = 30 sec in Study 1, the voltage across the capacitor:

choices.C: varied, but with no general trend.

The students constructed an electrical circuit consisting of the capacitor, which was initially uncharged, a 4-volt (4V) battery, a 1011-ohm resistor, and a switch (see Figure 1).

They closed the switch and charged the capacitor. During charging, the voltage across the capacitor, ε, in V, was monitored with a voltmeter. A computer that was connected to the voltmeter plotted ε versus time, t, in seconds (sec). The results are shown in Figure 2.

Once the capacitor was fully charged, ε equaled the voltage supplied by the battery. Using the data in Figure 2, the computer calculated the charge, Q, on the capacitor at various t, in picocoulombs (pC; 1 pC = 10-12 coulomb). The results are shown in Table 1.



Study 2
With the capacitor fully charged, the students opened the switch, removed the battery from the circuit, and substituted a picoammeter (see Figure 3) capable of measuring currents as small as 1 × 10-12 amp= 1 picoamp (pA). Then they closed the switch, allowing the capacitor to discharge through the resistor.


While the capacitor discharged, the students measured the electrical current, I, flowing through the resistor. The computer plotted I versus t (see Figure 4) and then, using the plotted values, calculated Q for various t (see Table 2).
questions.question: 18.  Based on Table 1 and Figure 2, as the capacitor was being discharged between t = 0 sec and t = 30 sec in Study 2, the voltage across the capacitor:

choices.C: varied, but with no general trend.

questions.title: Passage Ⅲ
questions.article:
A capacitor is a device for storing electrical charge. Students in a science class determined the charge on a parallel-plate capacitor having a fixed capacitance (the ratio of the amount of charge on each plate to the voltage between the plates). Measurements were taken while the capacitor was being charged and while it was being discharged.

Study 1
The students constructed an electrical circuit consisting of the capacitor, which was initially uncharged, a 4-volt (4V) battery, a 1011-ohm resistor, and a switch (see Figure 1).

They closed the switch and charged the capacitor. During charging, the voltage across the capacitor, ε, in V, was monitored with a voltmeter. A computer that was connected to the voltmeter plotted ε versus time, t, in seconds (sec). The results are shown in Figure 2.

Once the capacitor was fully charged, ε equaled the voltage supplied by the battery. Using the data in Figure 2, the computer calculated the charge, Q, on the capacitor at various t, in picocoulombs (pC; 1 pC = 10-12 coulomb). The results are shown in Table 1.



Study 2
With the capacitor fully charged, the students opened the switch, removed the battery from the circuit, and substituted a picoammeter (see Figure 3) capable of measuring currents as small as 1 × 10-12 amp= 1 picoamp (pA). Then they closed the switch, allowing the capacitor to discharge through the resistor.


While the capacitor discharged, the students measured the electrical current, I, flowing through the resistor. The computer plotted I versus t (see Figure 4) and then, using the plotted values, calculated Q for various t (see Table 2).

questions.title: Passage Ⅳ
questions.article:
Figure 1 is a simplified periodic table giving the name, symbol, and atomic number (number of protons in the nucleus) for 20 elements. The elements in a column belong to a group. The elements in a row belong to a period.

Table 1 gives the melting point at 1 atmosphere (atm) of pressure (the MP), the boiling point at 1 atm (the BP), and the atomic radius for one or more of the elements in each group. The atomic radius, in picometers (pm; 1 pm = 10-12 m), is a measure of the size of an atom. Table 1 also lists an ion for each element and the ionic radius of that ion (a measure of its size).
questions.question: 20.  According to Figure 1 and Table 1, which of the following graphs best shows how MP varies with atomic number for the Group 2A elements listed in Table 1 ?

questions.question: 24.  Which of the following statements comparing the ionic radius to the atomic radius for a given element is best supported by Table 1 ? Compared to the size of an atom, the size of the ion is:

choices.A: smaller, regardless of the charge on the ion.
choices.B: larger, regardless of the charge on the ion.
choices.C: smaller if the ion is negative, but larger if the ion is positive.
choices.D: larger if the ion is negative, but smaller if the ion is positive.

questions.title: Passage Ⅴ
questions.article:
Chickens can have different types of combs (red crests on the top of the head). Two unlinked genes that influence comb type in chickens are Gene R and Gene P. Table 1 lists 4 comb types in chickens and gives the Gene R and Gene P genotype(s) responsible for each comb type. In the genotypes, capital letters indicate dominant alleles and lowercase letters indicate recessive alleles.


Several chickens with the genotype Rrpp were crossed with chickens having the genotype rrPp. The percent of the resulting offspring having each comb type is shown in Table 2.
questions.question: 25.  Based on their genotypes for Gene R and Gene P, the parents in each of the Rrpp x rrPp crosses most likely had which comb type(s)?

choices.C: One parent had a walnut comb and the other parent had a pea comb.
choices.D: One parent had a rose comb and the other parent had a pea comb.

questions.title: Passage Ⅵ
questions.article:
Three cars were employed in a study of relative motion. Cars X and Y moved along an east-west highway. Car Z was always parked beside the highway between Cars X and Y (see Figure 1; figure not to scale).

During each trial, a passenger in each of the 3 cars used a radar gun to measure the velocities, in m/sec, of the other 2 cars. If 2 cars got farther apart, the velocity of each car, as measured from the other car, would be positive. If 2 cars got closer together, the velocity of each car, as measured from the other car, would be negative.

Table 1 lists the symbols used to represent the measured velocities. Table 2 gives the results of various trials.
questions.question: 30.  In which of the following trials was the distance between Car X and Car Y increasing?

questions.title: Passage Ⅶ
questions.article:
Calcium carbonate (CaCO3) is the primary component of chalk, eggshell, and other substances. When CaCO3 reacts with an acid, CO2 gas is produced:

CaCO3 + 2H+ Ca2+ + CO2 + H2O

Students did 2 experiments to determine the CaCO3 content of several common substances.

Experiment 1
A flask was fitted with an airtight cap. The cap contained a pressure sensor connected to a computer. Next, 30 mL of acid solution (a volume sufficient to react with up to 0.5 g of CaCO3) was added to the flask. Then, 0.01 g of powdered CaCO3 was added to the solution. The flask was quickly recapped, and pressure readings (in kilopascals, kPa) were recorded every 0.1 sec for 14 sec. The procedure was repeated using different masses of powdered CaCO3 (see Figure 1).


For each trial, the total change in pressure (△P) was calculated using the equation below:

△P = (maximum pressure) - (initial pressure)

The △P value for each trial was then plotted against the mass of CaCO3 added in that trial and a best-fit line was drawn through the points (see Figure 2).


Figures adapted from M. M. F. Choi and P. S. Wong, "Using a Data-logger to Determine First Order Kinetics and Calcium Carbonate in Eggshells." ©2004 by Division of Chemical Education, Inc., American Chemical Society.

Experiment 2
Students used the procedure from Experiment 1 to test 0.05 g samples of powders made from antacid tablets, calcium supplement tablets, and other substances. After calculating the △P value for each trial, they used the best-fit line in Figure 2 to convert each △P value to a mass of CaCO3, and then calculated the CaCO3 content (percent of the total mass that is CaCO3) for each substance using the equation below:


The results are shown in Table 1.
questions.question: 35. A 0.05 g sample of powdered seashell was tested as in Experiment 2. The CaCO3 content was calculated to be 81%. Based on Figure 2 and Table 1, △P for the seashell sample was most likely:

questions.title: Passage Ⅶ

questions.question: 37. A student claimed that, in Experiment 1, increasing the amount of CaCO3 that was added to the acid solution increased the reaction rate. Does Figure 1 support this claim?

choices.A: Yes, because the time to reach the maximum pressure was shorter in the trial for 0.05 g than it was in the trial for 0.01 g.
choices.B: Yes, because the time to reach the maximum pressure was longer in the trial for 0.05 g than it was in the trial for 0.01 g.
choices.C: No, because the time to reach the maximum pressure was shorter in the trial for 0.05 g than it was in the trial for 0.01 g.
choices.D: No, because the time to reach the maximum pressure was longer in the trial for 0.05 g than it was in the trial for 0.01 g.

questions.question: 38.  Which of the following assumptions must be made to properly interpret the results of Experiment 2?

choices.A: In each trial, the pressure stopped decreasing by time = 14 sec.
choices.B: In each trial, the pressure stopped increasing by time = 14 sec.
choices.C: Each of the substances tested was composed entirely of CaCO3.
choices.D: None of the substances tested contained CaCO3.

questions.question: 40.  Suppose 1 g of Supplement B were mixed with 1 g of eggshell to form homogeneous Powder X, and then 1 g of Antacid C and 1 g of cement were mixed to form homogeneous Powder Y.  Based on Table 1, if Powders X and Y were each tested as in Experiment 2, which powder would have a higher △P ?

choices.A: Powder X, because Powder X would have the higher CaCO3 content.
choices.B: Powder X, because Powder X would have the lower CaCO3 content.
choices.C: Powder Y, because Powder Y would have the higher CaCO3 content.
choices.D: Powder Y, because Powder Y would have the lower CaCO3 content.
